title: How to Quickly Create and Modify a Square Knot

steps.title: Lay the rope to your left on top of the rope to your right.
steps.content: Lay the rope to your left on top of the rope to your right. In our example, we'll lay the right-hand rope (the orange rope in the above graphic) over the left-hand (yellow) rope. [1] X Expert Source Jordan Frazier Knot Tying Expert Expert Interview. 02 January 2025. However, if you lay the left-hand rope over the right-hand rope instead, which may be more comfortable for some knotters, you can still tie a square knot using these directions—just reverse our instructions. If we ask you to adjust the left rope, adjust the right instead; if we ask you to tie the left rope, tie the right. [2] X Research source Alternatively, you can tie a square knot using just one rope, too. Hold one end in your left hand (going forward, this’ll be your left-handed rope) and one end in your right hand ( this will be your right-handed rope).

steps.title: Wrap the right-hand rope under the left-hand rope.
steps.content: Wrap the right-hand rope under the left-hand rope. The right-hand rope will now be wrapped around the left-hand rope, with the end of the right-hand rope positioned beneath the left-hand rope. [3] X Expert Source Jordan Frazier Knot Tying Expert Expert Interview. 02 January 2025. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Bring the right-hand rope back over the left-hand rope.
steps.content: Bring the right-hand rope back over the left-hand rope. Both ends of the ropes are now facing upward, and the right-hand rope has made 1 complete twist around the left-hand rope. At this point, you have what is known as a “half knot.” If you were to repeat the steps above again, you'd have tied an overhand knot [5] X Expert Source Jordan Frazier Knot Tying Expert Expert Interview. 02 January 2025. [6] X Research source . Note that these first 3 steps for making a square knot are the same as you'd use for tying your shoes.

steps.title: Lay the original right-hand rope over the left-hand rope.
steps.content: Lay the original right-hand rope over the left-hand rope. The end of the right-hand rope will be on the left at the start of this step, but it's still the rope that was originally on the right, so it's the rope you'll lay over the top here. [7] X Expert Source Jordan Frazier Knot Tying Expert Expert Interview. 02 January 2025. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Pull the original right-hand rope under and through the other rope.
steps.content: Pull the original right-hand rope under and through the other rope. This is virtually the same as in Step 2, just mirrored in the opposite direction since the original right-hand rope is now coming from the left. This knot is essentially the same knot twice, but in different directions each time. [9] X Expert Source Jordan Frazier Knot Tying Expert Expert Interview. 02 January 2025. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Tug on all the ends firmly to tighten.
steps.content: Tug on all the ends firmly to tighten. You now have four emerging lengths of rope: the two ends you used to tie the knot, and the rest of the two ropes. Pull all four "slack" lengths of rope with equal force. If you don't, the knot may not hold its shape and may even come apart as you tighten it. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Check and untie your square/reef knot.
steps.content: Check and untie your square/reef knot. From the front, your square knot should look like the one in the graphic above—a neat, even knot resembling two loops, with one loop wrapping around the base of the other. [12] X Expert Source Jordan Frazier Knot Tying Expert Expert Interview. 02 January 2025. Then, untying the square knot is simple—just grab the round part of each loop in your hands and pull in opposite directions. The knot will come apart easily. [13] X Research source . If you want to tie a stronger knot , opt for knots like bowlines, or a climbing knot like a figure eight follow-through knot.

steps.title: Form a loop with the left-hand rope, with the end positioned under the rest of the rope..
steps.content: Form a loop with the left-hand rope, with the end positioned under the rest of the rope.. Start with one rope in each hand (as you would in the method above) and fold the left-hand rope on top of itself to make a good-sized loop. This loop is called a “bight.” [14] X Research source This method will make a knot that's identical to the one in the method above. As above, you can make a loop with the right-hand rope and reverse the directions to get the same knot.

steps.title: Put the end of the right-hand rope down through the loop.
steps.content: Put the end of the right-hand rope down through the loop. [15] X Expert Source Jordan Frazier Knot Tying Expert Expert Interview. 02 January 2025. Pretend you’re threading a needle, with the looped rope as the eye of the needle. For the next several steps, curl your left index finger around the base of the loop to keep it together. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Bring the right-hand rope under the bottom of the loop.
steps.content: Bring the right-hand rope under the bottom of the loop. [17] X Expert Source Jordan Frazier Knot Tying Expert Expert Interview. 02 January 2025. Thread the right-hand rope through the loop. Pull it down and through—it should pass under the lower' half of the left-hand loop. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Bring the right-hand rope over the base of the loop.
steps.content: Bring the right-hand rope over the base of the loop. Pull the right-hand rope (the one that's threaded through the loop) and bring it up over the two ropes that come together at the base of the loop. If you're holding the loop in your left hand as directed, this will be at the left side of the loop. When you're done, the right-hand rope should be above the loop. [19] X Research source

steps.title: Bring the right-hand rope under the top of the loop and pull it through.
steps.content: Bring the right-hand rope under the top of the loop and pull it through. Finally, take the end of the right-hand rope (which is now to the left of the loop) and put it under the upper part of the loop. This mirrors the motion you made earlier on the bottom half of the loop. At this point, the right-hand rope is back "inside" the loop. Pull the right-hand rope through the loop. [20] X Research source

steps.title: Pull all four ends tight with even tension.
steps.content: Pull all four ends tight with even tension. Congratulations! Your knot should be exactly the same as the one you made in the method above. You can use either method to tie a square knot, so familiarize yourself and use whichever feels more comfortable to you. [21] X Research source

steps.title: Add extra half knots for added support.
steps.content: Add extra half knots for added support. To make your square knot a little stronger: once you’ve tightened your knot, repeat the over-and-under half knot pattern to create an additional half knot on top of the square knot. You can "stack" as many of these half knots as you'd like to give your knot additional strength. [22] X Research source Note that even "stacking" square knots in this way won't make your knot safe for critical usage. Don't use square knots (even stacked ones) for securing heavy loads or dangerous objects—they can (and do) fail. Instead, use a more secure knot like a Carrick bend or a Double Fisherman's knot.

steps.title: Add an extra coil in the square knot to make a surgeon's knot.
steps.content: Add an extra coil in the square knot to make a surgeon's knot. Another way to make your ordinary square knot a little stronger is to make what's called a surgeon's knot. To do this, after you wrap your right-hand rope over and under the left hand rope the first time, wrap it over and under again to create a second coil. After this, repeat the rest of the steps exactly as you normally would. You don't have to add an extra coil when you make the second half knot. [23] X Research source

steps.title: Use loops (rather than individual ropes) for the entire square knot.
steps.content: Use loops (rather than individual ropes) for the entire square knot. To tie this variation, simply start with one loop in each hand and treat each as you would treat individual ropes in the standard square knot instructions. In other words, the right-hand loop becomes the right-hand rope and the left-hand loop becomes the left-hand rope and the instructions are followed identically. [24] X Research source If you have long lengths of rope to use up (like, for instance, if your shoe laces are too long), you may want to try making a square knot with loops of rope (also called "bights") rather than single lengths of rope.
